The five-year accident history [40 CFR 68.155(d)]:
The Roehm Wallingford facility has not had any accidents or accidental releases as defined in 68.42 in the last five years.

The emergency response program [40 CFR 68.155(e)]:
The Wallingford Plant has a complete emergency response program. This program includes actions to be taken by operations, maintenance, utilities, office, technical, visitors, contractors, and plant emergency response employees. The onsite emergency response team drills periodically on various scenarios, which can include the Wallingford Fire Department and the site is active in the Wallingford Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). Drills with the Wallingford Fire Department are conducted and hands-on training for the responders is periodically provided. 

Planned changes to improve safety [40 CFR 68.155(f)]:
Roehm Wallingford is in the process of updating the controls and emergency safety systems including adding redundant controls, a dual fire protection system, additional LELs, and additional eStops to enhance the operations surrounding the acrylonitrile tank and rail car unloading area.

Roehm has completed this report to provide the public with information about our activities at this facility.  We believe that the many controls instituted to maintain a safe operation, and our commitment to continuous improvement that an incident affecting our employees or the surrounding area is unlikely to occur.

fety Review [PSSR] [40 CFR Part 68.77]
Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and modifications to existing processes are conducted routinely at Roehm Wallingford. These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating, and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits [40 CFR Part 68.79]
Roehm conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the US EPA RMP and OSHA PSM regulations are being implemented. These audits are conducted at least every 3 years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a prompt manner.

Incident Investigation [40 CFR Part 68.81]
Roehm promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring. All reports are retained for a minimum period of 5 years.

Employee Participation [40 CFR Part 68.83]
Roehm believes that Process Safety Management and accident prevention is a team effort. Employees are encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, Roehm employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP and PSM rules, including information resulting from Process Hazard Analyses in particular.

Hot Work Permit [40 CFR Part 68.85]
Roehm has a hot work permit that requires issuance of a hot work permit for hot work operations conducted on or near the covered process. 

Contractor Safety Program [40 CFR Part 68.87] 
Roehm occasionally hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the contractor's safety performance is carried out. Ro

The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated at a regular interval of 5 years. Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

Written Operating Procedures [40 CFR Part 68.69]
To ensure safe operations, Roehm maintains detailed written operating procedures. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations and normal shutdown. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.

Employee Training [40 CFR Part 68.71]
Roehm has a training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating plant processes are competent in the applicable operating procedures. Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed.

Mechanical Integrity [40 CFR Part 68.73]
Roehm carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations. Inspected process equipment include pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, pressure relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps. Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices. Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training as needed. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

Management of Change [MOC] [40 CFR Part 68.75]
Written procedures are in place at Roehm to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures. Facility operators or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification(s).

This is an executive summary of the policies, procedures, and activities for compliance with the EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Requirements - Risk Management Program pursuant to Title 40 Part 68 of the Code of Federal Regulations (40 CFR 68) for Roehm America, LLC facility located in Wallingford, CT.

The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source [40 CFR 68.155(a)]
Roehm America, LLC (Roehm) is dedicated to protecting safety, health and the environment. Our commitment is to protect our employees and the communities with our accidental release prevention program that incorporates design, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training.  Roehm has established safety, health, and emergency response and environmental policies and standards to meet all applicable regulatory requirements. The Wallingford facility maintains a permanent Fire Department located onsite and routinely trains for releases of the RMP-listed and/or otherwise hazardous chemicals.

The stationary source and regulated substances handled [40 CFR 68.155(b)]:
Roehm’s Wallingford facility manufactures acrylics that are used to make medical devices and other plastic products. The only RMP-regulated substance used above threshold quantity is Acrylonitrile.

The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps [40 CFR 68.155(c)]
Roehm has a program in place to comply with the provisions of the accidental release prevention regulations under 40 CFR Part 68. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the existing release prevention program.

Process Safety Information [40 CFR Part 68.65]
Roehm maintains records of process safety information that describe the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes.
